net.sf.clickclick.control.repeater
Class Repeater

java.lang.Object
  AbstractContainer
      net.sf.clickclick.control.repeater.Repeater
Direct Known Subclasses:
FieldRepeater
public abstract class Repeater
extends AbstractContainer

Provides a Repeater control for displaying a list of items. For every item in the list the Repeater will display the same specified components.

Usage

When creating a Repeater you must implement the abstract method buildRow(java.lang.Object, net.sf.clickclick.control.repeater.RepeaterRow, int) which is invoked by the Repeater for every item in the items list.

In the buildRow(java.lang.Object, net.sf.clickclick.control.repeater.RepeaterRow, int) method you setup the components for the given item and the Repeater will display these components for every item in the items list.

Basic Example

Given the Page MyPage.java: 
 public class MyPage extends Page {

     private Repeater repeater;

     public void onInit() {
         // Create a Repeater and implement the buildRow method
         repeater = new Repeater("repeater") {
             public void buildRow(Object item, RepeaterRow row, int index) {
                 // Form each item create a Field
                 Field field = new TextField("name");

                 // Set the Field value to the item's String representation
                 field.setValue(item.toString());

                 // Add the Field to the Repeater by adding it to the RepeaterRow
                 row.add(field);
             }
         };

         // Add the repeater to the Page
         addControl(repeater);

         // Create a list of items and set it as the Repeater item list
         List items = new ArrayList();
         items.add("one");
         items.add("two");
         repeater.setItems(items);
     }
 }
and the template my-page.htm: 
 $repeater
will render as:

How does the Repeater work?

In the example above a TextField is displayed for each item in the list. Both fields are called "name" and one can expect the fields to be rendered as: 
 <input type="text" name="name" id="name" ... />
 <input type="text" name="name" id="name" ... />
The two fields will have the same id and name, meaning it's not possible to differentiate the fields.

The Repeater resolves this issue by ensuring the name of child controls in each RepeaterRow is unique by adding the index of the row to each control. Thus the Repeater renders the two Fields as: 

 <input type="text" name="name_0" id="name_0" ... />
 <input type="text" name="name_1" id="name_1" ... />

Author:
Bob Schellink

buildRow

public abstract void buildRow(Object item,
                              RepeaterRow row,
                              int index)
This method is provided for users to build up the controls for the specified item.

For example: 

 public MyPage extends Page {

     Repeater repeater = new Repeater("repeater") {

         public void buildRow(final Object item, RepeaterRow row, int index) {

             final Customer customer = (Customer) item;

             final Form form = new Form("form");
             row.add(form);

             form.add(new TextField("firstname"));
             form.add(new TextField("lastname"));
             form.add(new TextField("age"));

             Submit submit = new Submit("submit");
             submit.setActionListener(new ActionListener() {

                 public boolean onAction(Control source) {
                     if (form.isValid()) {
                         form.copyTo(customer);
                         getCustomerService().save(customer);
                     }
                     return true;
                 }
             });
             form.add(submit);
         }
     }
 };

Parameters:
item - the item to build controls for
row - the RepeaterRow for the given item
index - the index of the given item

onProcess

public boolean onProcess()
Returns:
true if page processing should continue, false otherwise
See Also:
Control

copyToItems

public void copyToItems()
Copy the values of all Fields contained in a Repeater row to its associated item.

This method delegates to copyTo(java.lang.Object) for every item in the items list.

copyFromItems

public void copyFromItems()
Copy the values of each item in the items list to the Fields contained in the associated RepeaterRow.

This method delegates to copyFrom(java.lang.Object) for every item in the items list.

copyTo

public void copyTo(Object item)
Copy Field values from the item's associated RepeaterRow, to the given item's attributes. The specified item can either be a POJO (plain old java object) or a Map.

For more information on how Fields and Objects are copied see ContainerUtils.

Parameters:
item - the item to populate with field values

copyFrom

public void copyFrom(Object item)
Copy the given item's attributes into the Field values of the associated RepeaterRow. The specified item can either be a POJO (plain old java object) or a Map.

For more information on how Fields and Objects are copied see ContainerUtils.

Parameters:
item - the item to copy attribute values from

buildRows

protected void buildRows()
Build the rows for every Repeater item.

This method delegates to buildRow(java.lang.Object, net.sf.clickclick.control.repeater.RepeaterRow, int) for every item in the items list.

addIndexToControlNames

protected void addIndexToControlNames()
Adds an index to the name of child controls to ensure controls are unique within the Repeater.

Indexing is zero based, meaning controls contained in the first RepeaterRow will have "_0" appended to their names and controls contained in the second RepeaterRow will have "_1" appended.

For example, a control contained in the first RepeaterRow called "firstname" will be renamed to "firstname_0", and a control in the second RepeaterRow will be renamed to "firstname_1" etc.

removeIndexFromControlNames

protected void removeIndexFromControlNames()
Removes the index from the name of child controls.
